JEMIMA: Well, don’t hold back on my account!
DECAYED MASTER: Operate the Hostile Action Displacement System.
DOCTOR: (BEAT) Yes, very clever.
DECAYED MASTER: Isn’t it though?
JEMIMA: Well, I’m glad you’re so pleased with yourselves, but do you fancy sharing? What’s this hostile wotsit?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 51
DOCTOR: The HADS. In the event of an attack, it immediately translates the TARDIS to the nearest safe environment.
DECAYED MASTER: It doesn’t work temporally, it’s on a different circuit, so it should still be operational.
JEMIMA: So why aren’t you using that?
DECAYED MASTER: Because he’s bloody-minded, that’s why. We’re being fired on by a fleet of spaceships. By definition, the nearest safe environment is inside one of those ships. Specifically, the most secure and well-armoured one.
JEMIMA: The flagship.
DOCTOR: Precisely where he wants to go.
DECAYED MASTER: Oh, that one practically popped in to use the bathroom!
DOCTOR: You’re enjoying this, aren’t you?
DECAYED MASTER: Can I not have some fun once in a while?
DOCTOR: Not usually this much. (CURIOUS) Not in that incarnation...
JEMIMA: Doctor, I know you don’t want to give him what he wants, but maybe this is a good moment to swallow your pride. If there are these gaps in time everywhere, you need to be alive to fix them, don’t you?
JEMIMA: (PAUSE. THE DOCTOR POCKETS THE MASTER’S FORCEFIELD DEVICE AND
STARTS: OPERATING THE CONTROLS. A MISSILE APPROACHES ON THE SCREEN)
DOCTOR: Very well. I’ve switched on the HADS.
DECAYED MASTER: Good boy. And it seems you were just in time.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 52
BAUZA: Target neutralized, General. A direct hit.
NEW MASTER: No. No, it’s too simple... I know who’s in that box. I know how resourceful they are. They’re an old enemy of mine with a knack for eluding death... Initiate a temporal scan across the fleet. If anything changes, if there’s the faintest blip, I want to know about it. He’s here. Somewhere. And I’m going to find him.
NEW MASTER: (THE TARDIS MATERIALISES, IN A HADS STYLE. REF: ‘THE KROTONS’. CROSS
TO: )
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 53
DOCTOR: There we are. Looks like their missile bay. Satisfied?
DECAYED MASTER: Very much so, thank you.
DOCTOR: Now what? Are we heading out there?
DECAYED MASTER: We aren’t, no. You are. We’re staying here.
JEMIMA: Me? With you? Why can’t I go with him?
DECAYED MASTER: Because he won’t go unless I’ve got a gun pointed at your head, he’s terribly untrusting like that.
JEMIMA: What?
DOCTOR: He’s right, of course. I won’t let him harm you.
JEMIMA: I’m glad to hear it.
DOCTOR: What do you want me to do?
DECAYED MASTER: That’s the spirit! I want you to take him this.
JEMIMA: What? You’re giving him cigars?
DECAYED MASTER: No, this is far more than a cigar box, though I accept the appearance is similar.
DOCTOR: What’s in it?
DECAYED MASTER: Let’s not spoil the surprise. Take it to him.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 54
DOCTOR: I’m a Doctor, not a postman. Why can’t you give it to him yourself?
DECAYED MASTER: Because he and I are not on the best of terms presently. I ama man quite literally at war with myself.
DOCTOR: You’re fighting each other? Master versus Master?
DECAYED MASTER: I suppose you could put it that way.
DOCTOR: You’re saying he actually wants to kill you? But that’s ridiculous! He can’t kill you without destroying himself!
DECAYED MASTER: And yet it appears to be what’s happening.
DOCTOR: I can’t believe that.
DECAYED MASTER: You saw his hired assassins try to murder me in Upper Hexford, how can you doubt it?
DOCTOR: (BAFFLED) Upper Hexford?
DECAYED MASTER: Dear me, Doctor. Short-term memory is the first to go, they say. You and I had an encounter there, quite recently.
DOCTOR: We did?
DECAYED MASTER: Well, recently for me, for you it was a while back. I got myself rejuvenated and started looking for him, the other me.
DOCTOR: I don’t remember that.
DECAYED MASTER: You must. It would stick in the mind. My TARDIS up for auction? The Trans-Human Sisters on my tail? Those wretched, ungrateful children of mine?
DOCTOR: Children, what are you talking about?
JEMIMA: Eh?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 55
DECAYED MASTER: You must remember. It was you. Well, an older, younger you. The drippy blonde one. Wanders around dressed like nobody who’s ever played cricket ever. It was that you.
DOCTOR: And you were as you are now?
DECAYED MASTER: Yes!
DOCTOR: I don’t recall meeting this version of you in that incarnation.
DECAYED MASTER: (SOMEWHAT TROUBLED) Don’t you?
DOCTOR: It was always the one with the goatee beard and the taste for melodrama. When was this? Who was I travelling with?
DECAYED MASTER: You were alone.
DOCTOR: That could be a few occasions, I - (PAUSE) You know, there is an absence once, when I was him. Now you come to mention it. Somewhere around Little Hodcombe... How odd. A period of... nothingness.
JEMIMA: Like the gaps in time.
DOCTOR: Yes. Yes, exactly like that. Now I wonder why that’s happened?
DECAYED MASTER: I’m sure it won’t be anything to worry about. Well then. Are you going or not?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 56
NEW MASTER: Yes?
BAUZA: We’ve detected an unusual temporal signature in the missile bay, sir. It only registered after that craft’s apparent destruction.
NEW MASTER: (QUIETLY) I’ve got you. (ALOUD) Send a squad down. I want anyone or anything that emerges from that box brought to me. Immediately.
BAUZA: Sir.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 57
DECAYED MASTER: Off you pop then, Doctor. Give him the box, then get him to open a
DOCTOR: He won’t want to do that.
DECAYED MASTER: Make him.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure I want him to. Is it a bomb?
DECAYED MASTER: Nothing so crude. You’ll enjoy it, trust me. Now you understand? It’s vital he doesn’t know I’m here.
DOCTOR: I understand.
DECAYED MASTER: I’ll be watching you. Say anything more and she dies.
DOCTOR: I said I understood!
DECAYED MASTER: Then what are you waiting for? We’ve less than thirty minutes til the next time break! Allez-oop!
DOCTOR: T’ll come back for you, Jemima.
JEMIMA: I know.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 58
DOCTOR WHO: (THE DOCTOR EMERGES. DOZENS OF TROOPS ARE WAITING. THEY RACK THEIR
WEAPONS: )
GORLAN: Stop right there. Hands in the air.
DOCTOR: Oh.
GORLAN: Hands in the air!
DOCTOR: Quite the day for that, isn’t it? (HE RAISES THEM IN THE AIR)
GORLAN: What are you talking about?
DOCTOR: You wouldn’t understand. Take me to your Master.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 59
GORLAN: (DISTORT) You three, wait here. Guard the blue box. You, prisoner. This way!
GORLAN: (THE GORLAN GRINDS OUT OF THE ROOM WITH THE DOCTOR. THE DECAYED
MASTER: SWITCHES OFF THE MONITOR)
DECAYED MASTER: Excellent!
JEMIMA: Did you know he’d be captured that quickly?
DECAYED MASTER: I knew it was a possibility, yes. In fact, I was rather hoping he would.
JEMIMA: Oh? Why?
DECAYED MASTER: You’re full of questions, aren’t you? Questions, questions, questions, have you considered making a statement once in a while?
JEMIMA: Oh, I’ll make a statement, all right. I’ll make a statement. On your face.
DECAYED MASTER: Hmm, I’m pretty certain that’s nonsensical bravado, but at least you’re trying. No, the Doctor’s immediate capture means I’ll be able to commence my side of the plan sooner rather than later.
JEMIMA: You’re going out there? Of course. You’re up to something.
DECAYED MASTER: What gave it away? Well, young lady, I’m afraid that this is where we part company.
JEMIMA: You’re not taking me with you? Why not?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 60
DECAYED MASTER: Because you’re a tediously imbecilic example of a lesser species, and I’d rather not mooch around babysitting you when I could be doing something more interesting with my time, like staring vacantly at a wall.
JEMIMA: You’re not a very nice man, are you?
DECAYED MASTER: I’m glad you’ve noticed.
DECAYED MASTER: I’m terribly sorry, my dear, but you’ve outlived your usefulness.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 61
GORLAN: 2: Stop! Raise your hands in the air!
DECAYED MASTER: What? Dear boys, don’t you recognise me? I know carbon based life can be a little tricky for you chaps to distinguish between, but I can’t have changed that much, can I?
GORLAN: 2: Should we know you?
DECAYED MASTER: Of course. I’m your General. General Malgrove!
GORLAN: 2: You do not look like the general.
DECAYED MASTER: Scan me if you don’t believe me.
GORLAN: I will!
DECAYED MASTER: It was that fellow who left the box before me. He captured me. Tortured me. Left me for dead. Fortunately, I survived.
DECAYED MASTER: Well?
GORLAN: 2: You are the General!
DECAYED MASTER: See? I don’t want to say ‘I told you so’, but -
GORLAN: 2: My apologies, sir. To point my weapon at you. It was a... monstrous error.
DECAYED MASTER: Oh, not at all, not at all, it’s quite forgotten. Don’t trouble yourself. Now, if we could get on. I’m feeling a trifle discombobulated following my ordeal. I could do with a little lie down. Might you, perhaps, show me to my room?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 62
GORLAN: Prisoner as requested, General.
NEW MASTER: Excellent. Thank you.
GORLAN: I put the blue box under guard.
NEW MASTER: Good. Good. Doctor. What a pleasure to see you again.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry I can’t say the same to you.
NEW MASTER: And with a new face too. How delightful. You’re getting through them almost as quickly as me these days.
DOCTOR: (BEMUSED) A new... face?
NEW MASTER: What are you doing here, Doctor? Invading my stronghold alone is foolhardy even for you. You must have some ulterior purpose. I’d be gratified to learn of it before your annihilation. Just to ease my curiosity if nothing else...
DOCTOR: You know, I’m not entirely sure... You’ve not met my current persona before?
NEW MASTER: No. Last time was the carnival clown, don’t you remember?
DOCTOR: No. I don’t. And you looked like that?
NEW MASTER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Was it in your old prison, by any chance? Something to do with a Cermentine mind leach?
NEW MASTER: You know it was.
DOCTOR: Yes, I definitely don’t remember that. Interesting.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL)
NEW MASTER: An after-effect of your encounter with the leach.
DOCTOR: Perhaps. Or perhaps it’s another gap...
NEW MASTER: I don’t understand.
DOCTOR: No, but I’m beginning to.
NEW MASTER: Well, I’m sure discussing our relative appearances must be
NEW MASTER: Page 63
NEW MASTER: fascinating for someone, but it isn’t me. You will explain your purpose here before I count to three, or I will have you shot. One
DOCTOR: Oh, let’s not go that far. I’m here to bring you this.
NEW MASTER: A box? What’s in it?
DOCTOR: I’ve no idea. I didn’t pack it myself.
NEW MASTER: Then who did?
DOCTOR: I’m not at liberty to say. But I was told to bring it to you and to
DOCTOR: make you open it.
NEW MASTER: (TO GORLAN) You. Gorlan. Scan it.
GORLAN: Sir.
GORLAN: (THE GORLAN RUNS A PORTABLE SCANNING DEVICE OVER THE BOX.
BEEPS: ) Nothing registers as harmful, General.
NEW MASTER: Not a bomb? It doesn’t contain or virus, or something?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 64
GORLAN: No, sir.
NEW MASTER: I see. (PAUSE) What’s in it, Doctor? I know you of old. You’re not to be trusted. There’s some trick to this, I know there is.
DOCTOR: Like I say, I can’t help you. I simply don’t have the answers. Think of it as Schrodinger’s parcel, the contents will only exist when you prise it apart.
NEW MASTER: If you want me to open it, I suspect I probably shouldn’t.
DOCTOR: I don’t particularly want you to. I’m only trying to persuade you because a friend of mine dies if I don’t. (PAUSE) Tense, isn’t it?
NEW MASTER: Alright, you open the box. —- Gorlan, throw a protective shield around the prisoner. If anything comes out of that box, it’s not getting to me.
DOCTOR: You’re too kind.
NEW MASTER: Well do it.
DOCTOR: I suppose I have little choice in the matter.
DOCTOR: Oh.
NEW MASTER: What’s in it?
DOCTOR: Absolutely nothing.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page
DECAYED MASTER: Ah, yes, good. The main navigation controls. So many of then... Thank you, you’ve been a lot of help.
GORLAN: 2: I thought you’d have known where they were, General.
DECAYED MASTER: Yes, and that’s your problem. You didn’t think. Goodbye.
GORLAN: 2: (CRUMBLING) Aaaargh!
DECAYED MASTER: Now. Where to start, where to start...
DECAYED MASTER: 65
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 66
NEW MASTER: Gorlan! Lower the shield!
NEW MASTER: There’s got to be something inside that box.
NEW MASTER: Nothing. Literally nothing.
NEW MASTER: What are you up to, Doctor?!
DOCTOR: I’m not up to anything! I’m as surprised as you are.
NEW MASTER: Nice try. But I don’t believe you. Very well, if you won’t supply answers willingly, I may have to employ... special instruments of persuasion.
DOCTOR: It really won’t help.
NEW MASTER: What’s happening?
BAUZA: Sir, we’ve changed course.
NEW MASTER: Oh?
BAUZA: We’re now heading directly for the Hypertunnel relays.
NEW MASTER: Then change back.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 67
BAUZA: I’m trying to, sir. But the navigation systems aren’t responding. We can’t have more than twenty minutes.
NEW MASTER: If we crash into that relay, the ship will be destroyed! The tunnel too!
BAUZA: I know, sir. I’m trying my best...
NEW MASTER: This is your doing, Doctor. Somehow or other this is all down to
NEW MASTER: you.
DOCTOR: I can assure you it’s not.
NEW MASTER: (PAINED, BUT NOT AS MUCH AS THE GORLANS) What in -
DOCTOR: (PAINED, BUT NOT AS MUCH) No, he can’t be -
BAUZA: (AGONISED) Sir! Sir, please, help me, I can’t stand the - Aaarghhhh!
BAUZA: (SHE SHATTERS INTO A CLOUD OF DUST. ALL THE GORLANS AROUND THE
BRIDGE: FOLLOW SUIT)
DOCTOR: The Gorlans. They’re exploding! Get down!
DOCTOR: (THE NEW MASTER AND THE DOCTOR DUCK. THE TONE CUTS OUT. THE DUST SETTLES. THEY RISE)
NEW MASTER: No! Dead! They’re all dead!
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 68
DOCTOR: A sonic tone. Keyed to explode rock... leaving us the sole survivors...
NEW MASTER: (GRABBING HIM BY THE SCRUFF) What have you done? Everything was going so well. Then you! What was in this box?
DOCTOR: Nothing! It looks empty!
NEW MASTER: (SHOVING IT INTO HIS HANDS) Show me what it does!
DOCTOR: (FIDDLING WITH IT) I don’t know what it is!
DECAYED MASTER: Then I’1l tell you. A microscopic sonic generator. Keyed to Gorlan biology, via this vessel’s public address system.
NEW MASTER: No! Not... you!
DECAYED MASTER: You’ve lost your army, Master. That must be shattering.
NEW MASTER: No! (PRODUCING WEAPON) No, I’m not going back in there!
DOCTOR: See sense, Master! You can’t shoot your earlier self!
NEW MASTER: Can’t I?
NEW MASTER: (THE NEW MASTER FIRES HIS TCE AT THE DECAYED MASTER WHO DUCKS
AWAY: )
DECAYED MASTER: Missed!
DECAYED MASTER: (CALLING OUT AFTER HIM) Run all you like! You’re not getting away!
DOCTOR: He tried to shoot you! He really doesn’t care if you die!
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 69
DECAYED MASTER: Yes, I told you that. Didn’t you believe me? Come along. Back to your ship.
DOCTOR: But he’s escaping.
DECAYED MASTER: No he isn’t. He’ll be heading for his quarters. That’s where he left his TARDIS. As least... that’s what he thinks.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 70
NEW MASTER: No! Where is it? What have you done with my TARDIS?!
NEW MASTER: Yes?
BARON: (COMMUNICATOR DISTORT) General, your ship appears to be heading directly for the Hypertunnel -
NEW MASTER: Yes, yes, I’d noticed.
BARON: (DISTORT) Might I remind you in the strongest terms -
NEW MASTER: Quiet, fool. I do not have time for your inanities!
NEW MASTER: I said I do not have time!
DECAYED MASTER: (DISTORT) Now, now, no need to be rude, is there? We go back a
DECAYED MASTER: long way.
NEW MASTER: You! Tell me! Where is my TARDIS?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 71
DOCTOR WHO: (THE DECAYED MASTER SPEAKS INTO A COMMUNICATOR, THE DOCTOR TO ONE SIDE)
DECAYED MASTER: (CHUCKLES) Now, now, that would be telling.
NEW MASTER: (DISTORT) I will destroy you for this!
DECAYED MASTER: Then you’ll never get off this crate, will you? Can’t have long now before it crashes, can we? I imagine it’ll be a pretty big boom.
NEW MASTER: (DISTORT) What do you want?
DECAYED MASTER: Oh, a chat, just a chat. Three minutes. The missile bay. Be there.
DOCTOR: Was that wise?
DECAYED MASTER: Doctor. I think it’s time to clear the air.
DOCTOR: What’s that you’re holding?
DOCTOR: Urgh!
DECAYED MASTER: Oh. Not air freshener. Knock out gas. I really should label these
DECAYED MASTER: things more carefully.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 72
ALERT: Proximity alert. Collision imminent. Please abandon ship.
ALERT: (THIS REPEATS REGULARLY AFTER A SHORT PERIOD. THE DECAYED MASTER IS TYING THE DOCTOR TO A CHAIR, TIGHTENING KNOTS)
DECAYED MASTER: Morning! Did you sleep well? Now, now. Don’t struggle.
DOCTOR: (WEAK) Oh great. Tied to a chair again... Always ready to double cross me, aren’t you?
DECAYED MASTER: You’d feel betrayed if I didn’t.
NEW MASTER: (DISTANT) You know, I could shoot you in the back right now, Master. Then I’d be free. I could steal the Doctor’s TARDIS and escape.
DECAYED MASTER: The key to the Doctor’s TARDIS is hidden as well as your own ship. You’re not escaping this craft’s imminent immolation unless I say so, and you know what I want!
NEW MASTER: (DISTANT) I’d rather die! I’11 kill you before I go back there!
DECAYED MASTER: Oh, I don’t think you’1ll have to. Come on. Join us. You might see things more clearly.
NEW MASTER: (TAKING IN THE SCENE) But... I don’t understand. You’ve tied him up, you’re not working with him?
DECAYED MASTER: We were, sort of. But you know how it is with the Doctor, collaboration never ends well.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 73
NEW MASTER: Who are you? Who resides in that cadaverous form?
DECAYED MASTER: (THROWN) You... don’t know?
DOCTOR: (ALMOST FULLY RECOVERED) He might not, but I do.
NEW MASTER: Oh?
DOCTOR: I should have realised sooner. The Master with the decayed face is usually quite a serious sort. Cold, cruel. But this time round he’s been enjoying himself a little too much. He’s been playful, insane. More the sort of personality I’d associate with you. And you seem somewhat subdued. Almost as if you’d switched bodies.
NEW MASTER: What?
DOCTOR: He’s you. I mean, there’s more to it than that, obviously. He’s the future you. Not on the outside, of course. That’s your past. I’m talking about the creature within.
NEW MASTER: I don’t understand.
DOCTOR: Neither do I, not really. But it’s the only thing that makes sense. Although I use the word ‘sense’ loosely.
NEW MASTER: (STRUGGLING TO DEAL WITH IT) I - (GATHERS HIMSELF) So - what happened? I know I took this shell off... someone, but I... struggle to recall the details. You’re saying it’s the body of my future self...? I stole the body from my future self?
DOCTOR: Well, I don’t know precisely what happened, but presumably, yes.
NEW MASTER: I don’t understand. How can this be?
DECAYED MASTER: It doesn’t matter in the slightest. I am not pleased to be contained within this walking corpse again. Whether you knew my identity or not, that is still my body you’re squatting in. And I would like it back.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 74
NEW MASTER: Don’t make me return to that... thing...
DECAYED MASTER: Oh, I won’t. I remember those days. The pain is almost unendurable. I feel it now. I would never condemn myself to this. Not even an earlier me, not even one I thought an enemy. I might have detested you for your betrayal but I had at least planned to offer an alternative.
NEW MASTER: What alternative?
DECAYED MASTER: You know when people say they wouldn’t wish something upon their own worst enemy? Well... I would.
DOCTOR: Ah.
DECAYED MASTER: And now you know why I brought you here, Doctor.
NEW MASTER: I see. It is... ingenious.
DECAYED MASTER: I tried to steal his form in Hexford. It didn’t work out, but it gave me an idea. I return my mind to its original body. You place your mind in the Doctor’s. Take it over, leaving him only one place to retreat to.
NEW MASTER: That decaying husk.
DECAYING MASTER: Exactly. He’ll be trapped in this prison of pain for the rest of his life. Which, seeing as he’s in a shrinking island of time and on a ship due to explode very shortly, won’t be more than five minutes, but you can’t have everything.
DOCTOR: You can’t do this.
NEW MASTER: Oh, I think we can!
DECAYED MASTER: Isn’t it glorious? In one fell swoop we’ll be rid of the Doctor, and of this disgusting lump of flesh. Rid of them both. Forever!
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 75

elements.text: PART THREE
OPENING THEME
39. INT. CLOISTERS
CONTINUED FROM SCENE ONE. THE NEW MASTER IS HIMSELF CURRENTLY
I am the Master. And you... know the rest.
The Master.
In the flesh.
The notorious renegade Time Lord. Destroyer of worlds. Murderer of billions.
Oh, stop, stop, you’re making me blush.
The Master? Father Sebastian, we must destroy him. He will betray us!

No. No, Salron, I do not think he will. If he wished our endeavours neutralized, he could easily have eliminated us when he arrived, when we were not aware of his presence. And yet we still live. Why?
I do not know.
Come on, come on, you can do it.
He requires something of us...
Exactly, you’re very astute. I suppose that’s why you’re Cult Leader and not just some common or garden cultist, like Salron here.
Tell us then. What is it that you desire?
Why, like I said. To help you, dear chap, just to help you. What else could I want?
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 76
BEAT
You are... familiar with my brethren? With our ideology?

Oh yes. The Cult of the Heretic. Quite a cosmopolitan group, aren’t you? I count, what... a dozen species? I have to say, you’ve worked awfully hard to convince the universe you didn’t exist. The false trails, the double bluffs, the secrets and the lies. It would take a genius to untangle them. And it did.
The universe would destroy us if it knew we were real.
With good reason, I mean, you do want it dead after all. So, thanks to your manipulation and persuasion, you are believed to be a myth, a legend. A bedtime story to scare little ones of all species.
And yet you found us. You knew the stories were true.

Well. When you’ve allied yourself with as many myths as I have, you learn not to take these things at face value. I found out about the Heretic from the Time Lords’ secret files. He was one of my people, you know?
So I believe.
And it was my people who killed him. Dissipated his atoms to the
cosmos. They’re like that.
Curse them. Curse the Time Lords!
And that’s your problem, isn’t it? He was rather vital to the scheme. Without Time Lord involvement, his dream could be a little tricky to realise.
We will find a way.

Will you? I mean, seriously, will you? It’ll be an awful lot of faff, experimenting here, investigating there. Why go to all that bother when you’ve got me? Now. Ready to donate my biological data. At a cost.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 77
What cost?
Oh, I think you can guess.
PAUSE
Well?
We would have conference. You appreciate we cannot make a decision
of this import without some discussion.
Of course, certainly, don’t mind me, talk as much as you like. I’ve got all day.
Brethren. Let us leave this place.
As you wish.
THEY FILE OUT
I’ll just stay here and put my feet up. Don’t worry. I’ve got a good book...
HE PULLS OUT A PAPERBACK AND RIFLES IT OPEN
FADE OUT
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 78
40. INT. CLOISTERS (LATER
THE MASTER IS CHUCKLING AS HE READS. THE CULT FILES IN
Oh, you’re back. That’s sooner than I expected. I’1l have to save the Great Glass Elevator for another day.
HE POPS THE BOOK AWAY
It is agreed. We will grant you that which you desire. You may rule.
Excellent. I knew I could trust you chaps and chapesses to do the wrong thing.
Only... there is... a condition.
PAUSE
Don’t try my patience, Sebastian.
You require something of us; well, we require something of you.
I am not accustomed to taking orders. I am the Master. There’s a clue in the name.
It is what we need. It is nothing onerous. Merely... a declaration of intent.
I could show you a declaration of intent you wouldn’t be happy with. I am remarkably expert at murder.
Threaten me all you wish, Time Lord. We are as one. If I die my brethren shall replace me, one by one. They shall make the same request.
Then I’ll reply to them in the same way.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 79

And kill all of us? We are not afraid of death. We serve a higher cause. But you - you need us. You cannot perform this act alone. You need our information, otherwise why come here? — The Time Lords have not been able to create an Anomaly Cage of their own, have they?
I will admit that the Heretic was a unique thinker. His designs have proved impossible for even our finest minds to replicate.
And if they cannot replicate it, you cannot steal it. We are the only ones offering that technology. Therefore you will not destroy us.
PAUSE
What do you want?
PAUSE
We want you to kill yourself.
PAUSE
Yes, I’m intrigued by your definition of the phrase ‘nothing onerous’.
You think too conventionally, Time Lord. You know what the Cage does.
I have the rough idea, yes.
Then you know such an act will cause you no harm whatsoever.
Is this your first language? I have to see what dictionary you’re using.
We do not mean you of the now. We mean you of the past.
BEAT
Oh.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page
And now you comprehend.
Destroy my past self, change history that completely... my only possible means of survival is through using the Cage.
Precisely. You must prove your commitment to the cause.
Yeah, that’d do it. Well, it’s ingenious, I’ll give you that.
But what say you?
You ask a great deal.
No more than you ask of us. You want the power only we can provide? Prove to us you are worthy of it.
PAUSE
Let me tell you, I am awfully hard to kill.
Even for you? I believe you're... ‘remarkably expert at murder’.
Touché.
PAUSE

Very well. Most of my former selves have been incompetent wastrels. They got through lives at the drop of a hat. Their continued survival is of little consequence to me. Only my own ongoing existence matters.
Then you will do it?
Of course I’ll do it! Gladly! If one of them must die a little earlier than otherwise, well... they should have been more careful, shouldn’t they? They deserve to die. Every last one of them.
Good. Good. Then it is agreed.
Yes. And I know exactly where to do it.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 81
41. TIME LORD VAULT CONTROL CENTRE
(A TIME LORD COMPUTER ALERT PINGS - REF: THE DEADLY ASSASSIN. A
LORD OPERATES CONTROLS )
Terserus Base. This is Terserus Base. Would the approaching TARDIS please identify itself. You are not authorised to land here. Identify yourself by the order of the High Council.
NO RESPONSE. THE TIME LORD TAPS MORE CONTROLS

Unidentified TARDIS. This is a top security installation. If you do not identify your craft voluntarily we will be forced to identify it for you. And if needs be, meet your approach with lethal force.
NO RESPONSE. HE OPERATES MORE CONTROLS
Identification programs running.
DATA CHITTERS ACROSS HIS SCREEN
Scanning. Scanning.
IT BEEPS. AND THEN THE FLARE OF AN EVEN MORE STRIDENT ALERT
The Master!
(HE HITS A CONTROL. AN ALARM RINGS OUT ACROSS THE BASE. HE OPERATES A COMMUNICATOR)
All personnel, this is Control. We have a hostile approaching, the renegade known as the Master, he is presumed armed and dangerous.
Red alert, repeat red alert, everyone on standby.
(HE SWITCHES OFF THE COMMUNICATOR. A DOOR SLIDES OPEN BEHIND HIM. THE NEW MASTER STEPS IN)
Galsar, have you seen this, the Master’s coming, he’s just about to [land -]
THE NEW MASTER SHOOTS HIM
Argh!
No, I’m not, I’ve been here for hours. Picking off the rest of your crew. Now that’s enough of that...
HE SWITCHES OFF THE ALARM
[CONT’D]
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 82
Awful racket.
HE OPERATES SOME CONTROLS
[CONT'D] Incoming TARDIS, you are free to land, repeat, free to land. Chocks away. Don’t mind me. Thank you.
(HE CLOSES THE BASE COMMUNICATOR THEN OPERATES ANOTHER COMMUNICATOR OF HIS OWN)
Well. He bought it. Relative temporal arrival time... five minutes.
SEBASTIAN REPLIES OVER THE COMMUNICATOR
(DISTORT) You have done well.
I usually do. Though I couldn’t have done it without your teleport, Father Sebastian.
(DISTORT) Low-level technology, I admit. But their defences were designed to combat more sophisticated incursions.

Very clever. Second time I’ve broken into this place. Though that was later in its life, obviously. They really should look into their security. You’re sure you won’t join me? To see the... ‘coup de grace’?
(DISTORT) Our current location is perfectly adequate. We are not as bloodthirsty as you.
Too scared to leave your little sanctuary, more like.

(DISTORT) Believe what you wish, we are not sadists. The scanners you have installed will prove sufficient witness. But be quick. Once the deed is done. The second your earlier incarnation is obliterated, your timeline will start unravelling. You will need to make haste for the Anomaly Cage if you wish to survive.

And you’re only going to tell me its location when I’ve killed him. Yes, yes, I know. I mean, really, whatever happened to trust? Go on. You can tell me now. What difference will it make? Didn’t your mothers ever talk to you about sharing?
(DISTORT) You know the agreement.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 83
Can’t blame a guy for trying. Very well. I will make contact again when the deed is done. Master out.
HE SWITCHES THE COMMUNICATOR
Though if you think it’ll be as simple as that, you’ve another think coming. Well, now. Best get ready.
HE EXITS
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 84
42. INT. TIME LORD VAULT LANDING BAY
(THE DECAYED MASTER’S TARDIS MATERIALISES. SILENCE FOR A FEW SECONDS. THEN HE EMERGES, DOOR OPENING WAR-GAMES STYLE. HE’S NOT
DECAYED)
PRE-DECAYED MASTER:
Well? I’m waiting. You’ve fulfilled your first promise, you got me in here. Now what about the second?
HE STEPS INTO THE ROOM
Come out, come out, wherever you are...
HE EXITS TO THE NEXT ROOM
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 85
43. INT. TIME LORD VAULT ANTE-ROOM (CONTINUOUS
THE DECAYED MASTER ENTERS
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Hmmm. Dead bodies everywhere. My kind of ally, if nothing else.
THE DOOR SHUTS BEHIND HIM
What in - ?
THE NEW MASTER STEPS FORWARD
Hello there.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Ah. I presume you are my benefactor?
Yes, you could say that.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER:

The Time Lord vaults. The store of all their forbidden knowledge. I have long desired to infiltrate these hallowed halls. Thank you for facilitating my arrival. (BEAT) Do I know you from somewhere? Your face feels like it should be familiar...
And yours does too. Oh, to think. I’d almost forgotten what it looked like before...
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Before... what?
I almost regret it. I’ve often wondered what killed me here. My mind was curiously foggy on that point. Turns out it was me... Well, that’s a twist.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: What are you talking about?
You know, I don’t think I’ve ever meant this quite as sincerely before, but believe me - this is nothing personal.
HE STARTS PULLING OUT HIS TCE...
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Oh no you don’t —-
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 86
(... BUT THE DECAYED MASTER IS QUICKER, AND BLASTS HIM WITH A STASER, THE TCE DROPPING)
Aagh! My hand!
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Ah. I see you have your own Tissue Compression Eliminator? Should I be flattered? Copying me, are you?
(PAINED) Not exactly.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER:

You’re behind the times. I’ve been using a staser lately. I like to mix things up a bit. (CHUCKLES) Did you really believe me so naive as to trust you? An anonymous contact offers vital knowledge leading to the destruction of the Time Lords? Of course it was a trap, I am no fool.
Aren’t you?
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: I am far more intelligent than you will ever be.
BEAT
Well, you say that — but are you faster? (LEGS IT)
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Stop! Stop!
HE BLASTS AGAIN, BUT MISSES
(RUNNING OFF) Catch me if you can!
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: You think you can escape me. It will be my pleasure to disabuse
you of that notion.
HE HEADS AFTER THE NEW MASTER
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 87
44. INT. TIME LORD VAULT CORRIDOR
(THE NEW MASTER CHARGES DOWN THE CORRIDOR. HE RECEIVES A CALL ON
COMMUNICATOR. HE ANSWERS IT)
(RUNNING) Yes, Sebastian, what do you want? I’m busy...
(DISTORT) Your sensors indicate your younger self is still alive. Things do not appear to be going to plan. It seems you underestimated him.
Oh, I don’t think so. If there’s one person in the universe I never underestimate, it’s myself. I have the highest possible opinion of me.
(DISTORT) Then this is -
- all part of the plan, yes. So if you’ll forgive me -
HE SWITCHES THE COMMUNICATOR OFF AND STOPS RUNNING
Now where - ah, yes.
HE DARTS DOWN A SIDE CORRIDOR AS THE DECAYED MASTER NEARS
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: You cannot hide. I will find you.
HE FOLLOWS HIS NEW SELF
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 88
45. INT. TIME LORD VAULT TRAP ROOM
THE DECAYED MASTER RUNS INTO THE ROOM
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Your agonising demise is merely a matter of - Aaaargggh!
(HE’S BEEN CAUGHT IN A FIELD OF ENERGY —- LIKE AN ELECTRIC FENCE. IT BURNS. THE NEW MASTER EMERGES FROM WITHIN THE ROOM)
There, that’s better.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: What have you done? What is this?

A Malson Electrofield. A sort of energy net. Very nasty. You won’t be able to move, so don’t bother trying. I out-thought you, you see. You anticipated my betrayal, well, I anticipated your anticipation. Factored it in. You’re very easy to trick, dear boy. We think the same way.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: I will escape this mesh. And you will regret your actions.
No, don’t think so. It was never going to be the TCE, I knew that. That’s not how it happened, the first time. I remember. I was burnt. Burnt to a crisp.
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: What say you?
Oh, don’t worry. You’1ll work it out. Eventually. Now, let’s see, how does this thing work?
HE TWISTS A DIAL. THE ENERGY LEVEL BUILDS
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Yaaarggggh!
Oh, does that hurt? Yes, I suppose it does. Look, sorry about all this, but I really am acting in your best interests.
HE TWISTS THE DIAL AGAIN, AND THE ENERGY BUILDS AGAIN
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Yaaarrrghhhh!
This is for your own good you know.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 89
ANOTHER TWIST. ANOTHER ENERGY BUILD
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Yaaargggggh!
Don’t shout. I’m trying to concentrate! This is a very delicate operation. I need you left a fraction above death...
HE TWISTS AGAIN, MORE ENERGY
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: Yaaaargggghhhhh!

.then if I abandon your dying body, they’ll think I’ve fulfilled my side of the bargain... but they don’t know what happens next. If I Signal Gallifrey, a certain Chancellor might just wing his way over here and rescue you. Everyone wins. I’m doing you a favour, really.
HE TWISTS THE DIAL A FINAL TIME. BIGGEST PULSE OF ENERGY
PRE-DECAYED MASTER: (GOING INTO A SLUMP) Yaaaarrrggggghhhh...!!!
Ah. Yes. Looks like that’s the ticket. Well. All I have to do now is - (BLASTED FROM BEHIND) Urgh!
What in - (HE’S BLASTED AGAIN) Urgh!
(HE DROPS. FEET WALK ACROSS TO THE BODY, PICK UP THE FIELD CONTROLS, AND SWITCH IT OFF. THE DECAYED MASTER - NOW ACTUALLY
- COLLAPSES TO THE GROUND. THE FEET APPROACH HIM. FROM
ON, THE DECAYED MASTER STRUGGLES WITH PAIN, CLOSE TO DEATH)
(RASPING, AGONISED) Who... who are... You... saved me...
Yes. We have.
THE CULTISTS ENTER THE ROOM
Do you require assistance?
Where did you come from?
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 90
We teleported in shortly after he did. But we waited. Out of Sight. For just this moment.
Oh?
Remove the other one, Salron.
Brothers, help me.
THE CULTISTS DRAG THE NEW MASTER OUT
What are you doing with hinm...?
Taking him to our domain. You may follow. And see.
RISING) I - (GASP OF PAIN) Ahh! (HE DROPS
Oh. Of course. You must be close to death. I will assist you. Be
careful - the teleport may prove painfull...
HE HELPS THE STRUGGLING MASTER FROM THE ROOM. FADE
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 91
45. INT. CLOISTERS TELEPORT STATION
THE BUZZ OF A TELEPORT. SEBASTIAN AND THE DECAYED MASTER APPEAR
Please, I... cannot live long... like this...
Long enough, I would hope.
What is this place?
Our cloisters. Come. This way...
HE LEADS THE DECAYED MASTER INTO THE NEXT ROOM. FADE
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 92
46. INT. CLOISTERS TRANSFER STATION
(SEBASTIAN HELPS THE DECAYED MASTER IN. A BIG MACHINE WHIRRS OFF. THE NEW MASTER IS BEING PLACED WITHIN)
Ah. All is nearly prepared.
What have you done to him?
Nothing. Yet. Is... ‘he’... installed correctly?
Very soon.
And we have the required biodata?
The scan is running, it will soon complete.
Good.
What is that machine...?
A mental transference unit.
I do not understand.
He tried to murder you. He failed. What sweet revenge it would be for you to place his mind inside your expiring body and... take over his?
I could... I could do that?
Oh yes. Through that machine, it is simplicity itself. And your only possible means of survival.
This is my last regeneration. If this body dies...
I know.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 93
We will save you.
Save me? Why would you do that?
Why? Because it is the right thing to do.
The right thing? No. No-one would help me live through pure altruism. You have some ulterior motive...
Whether we do or not hardly matters. We are your only option for survival. Well?
PAUSE
Who was he? Why did he wish to kill me?
Does it matter?
PAUSE
No. It does not. (BEAT) Do it.
FADE
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 94
47. INT. CLOISTERS TRANSFER STATION [FEW MINUTES LATER]
(DECAYED MASTER IS BEING PLUGGED INTO THE MACHINE — METAL CLAMPS ETC)
There. He is ready.
Will the procedure be quick? This body has little time left...
It shall be quick enough. We may proceed.
HE OPERATES THE MACHINE. MORE WHIRRING ENERGY
Will it hurt?
Probably.
(HE SLAMS A LEVER DOWN. BIG BURST OF ENERGY, BUZZING. THE MASTERS REACT IN AGONY )
MASTER/DECAYED MASTER: Gaaaah!
Do not worry. All goes precisely to plan. You may feel agony now, but in time, you will never have existed at all. So it matters not.
(JUST HOLDING ON, GRITTED TEETH) Never... have... existed?
No one will. Apart from us. The universe is sick, my friend. Soon,
very soon... it shall regenerate.
SOUNDS SPEED UP - AND WE RETURN TO THE PRESENT
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 95
48. INT. WARSHIP (MISSILE BAY
(FADE UP REPRISE OF 38. THE MASTERS ARE BACK IN THEIR ALTERNATIVE PERSONALITIES. THE ALERT CONTINUES IN THE BACKGROUND)
[..] I return my mind to its original body. You place your mind in the Doctor’s. Take it over, leaving him only one place to retreat to.
That decaying husk.

Exactly. He’ll be trapped in this prison of pain for the rest of his life. Which, seeing as he’s in a shrinking island of time and on a ship due to explode very shortly, won’t be more than five minutes, but you can’t have everything.
You can’t do this.
Oh, I think we can!
Isn’t it glorious? In one fell swoop we’ll be rid of the Doctor, and of this disgusting lump of flesh. Rid of them both. Forever!
SCENE CONTINUES:
No, I mean you really can’t do this. It’s impossible.
Don’t try to bluff us, Doctor, you will fail.
To us, nothing is impossible.
Think about it. The gaps in history. The blank pages, if you like.
What about them?
Blank pages?
Those islands of time your other self mentioned. Time is being wiped out. Patches of non-time spreading everywhere, everywhen. Throughout the universe. Like a disease.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 96
They’re not important. We’ve flown around them before, we’ll fly around them again. Just in slightly different bodies.
Oh, will you? Are you sure? Time itself is being erased. Isn’t it obvious why?
No, but I’m sure you will inform us of the answer in your usual oh So superior way.
It’s you two. It’s your fault.
PAUSE
Doctor, if I was destroying the universe, I think I’d know about it, I’ve done it often enough.
That body, there. The later model.
Me?

Yes. It only exists because the earlier you didn’t possess it now. The earlier you, the one inside there, was left to die on Terserus, and eventually regenerated into that form. It’s your future self from a timeline where this didn’t happen.
I suppose so.
Go on.

So by taking over it now, you make it an impossibility. It can no longer be created. And if it can’t be created, it can’t be there to be taken over. You see where I’m going with this? It’s sort of like killing your own grandfather. Only in reverse.
I... see...
You’re now both walking temporal anomalies. In your current forms you cannot exist, yet you do. And you know how time abhors a paradox.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 97
You think that’s what’s causing the time breaks?

Don’t you? You want proof? You both claim to have met me recently in some of my earlier incarnations. Well, I have no memory of those meetings. Almost as if history is breaking down around those points. The points you’ve travelled to as you presently are.
This is all speculation. There’s no temporal theory to the effect.

Because there’s no precedent for this level of madness. You’re acting like a computer virus on time - a ‘reality virus’, if you will. Wherever you go, you infect it. The longer you stay in the wrong bodies, you’re destroying all history.
As long as we stay in the wrong bodies, precisely. But we have no intention of remaining in them. When we return, the effect will cease.

Ah, but you’re not returning, are you? Not both of you. You want to place his mind in my head. That won’t stop it. That’s still not what happened in your past, I can’t regenerate into this latest you. One of you will still be an impossibility, so the effect will
continue.
PAUSE
Do you believe him?
This incarnation of the Doctor is a wily one. He could be lying.
Can you take the risk? If I’m right, and you ignore me, the universe will collapse around you. Rather a pyrrhic victory, wouldn’t you say?
PAUSE
I can’t return. Not to that decaying monstrosity. I can’t.
It need not be for long.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 98

Far be it from me to interrupt your delicate negotiations, but might I remind you that we’re on a spaceship that’s crashing into a hypertunnel? And rapidly approaching a period of non-existence? You really don’t have the time for detailed deliberations. You can make your choice later. For now, I have to fly us out of here.
You? Why can’t we just leave you here?
Because I don’t believe your TARDIS was damaged by traversing the empty time periods.
Mine?
You remember, you said you were having difficulty piloting it? I believe it’s been reacting to you just like the universe has. By breaking down. If you try to fly mine, you’ll hurt it just as badly.
You can’t know that.
Maybe not, but there’s an easy way to find out. You didn’t know about the gaps, did you?
Me?
Yes. So you can’t have flown through them. How’s your TARDIS been working?
It has had... some difficulties.
See? You need me.
PAUSE
No. No we don’t.
You... don’t?
Oh, my dear Doctor. You have miscalculated.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 99
(GETTING IT) Ah, of course, yes, that is magnificent!
I don’t understand.
I hate existing as a walking corpse, existing in that husk of a body. But I hate you more. The one thing that could persuade me to return to it... is the guarantee of your death. Contact!
Contact!
No!
BUT HE’S TOO LATE. CUT TO:
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 100
49. INT. MINDSCAPE (CONTINUOUS
CONTACT SOUND EFFECT FROM THREE DOCTORS, LIGHT AT THE END, ETC.
Come now. It’s time to come home.
Yes. Yes I suppose it is.
(AND WITH A ROAR OF ENERGY, NOT UNLIKE THE ANDROZANI REGENERATION, THEIR MINDS TRANSFER AND WITH A BANG —- )
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 101
50. INT. WARSHIP (MISSILE BAY) (CONTINUOUS
(THE MASTERS HAVE RETURNED TO THEIR ORIGINAL FORMS — ‘STANDARD’ PERFORMANCES FROM THIS POINT)
Oh, yes. Yes, that’s more like it. Thank you! It’s good to be back.
No.
Ah. This familiar cage... (REMEMBERS SOMETHING) Cage... Something about... a cage.. Why do I remember that?
You can’t leave me here.
You’re really not an expert on what we can and can’t do, are you, Doctor? Leaving you on a warship that’s going to crash into a hypertunnel and explode is very much within our remit.
But there’s more to it than that! The universe is dying. History is dying. You’ve nowhere to run.
(GASP OF REALISATION) Ah, I believe we do! The Anomaly Cage!
The what?
I saw it in your mind as a place of safety! But the details are... unclear... What is an Anomaly Cage?

I’ve no idea what you’re banging on about, I’ve never heard of an — (MEMORY RETURNING) Ah! Yes! The fog clears. The Cult! The Cult of the Heretic! Of course. A bit of contact’s always good for defragging the old noggin.
The Cult of the Heretic. Oh, this just gets worse.
For you, maybe. I’m kind of alright with it all.
What is this Cult?
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 102
I’ll explain later. But I think we’ve uncovered who thought to betray us...
It was they who sent the assassins? The Dragonhunters? The Trans- human Sisters of the Unholy Protocol?
Yes, at a guess. I must say, I don’t like it when people try to kill me. It’s so terribly impolite. But, yes, I think the Anomaly Cage should prove perfectly adequate for our requirements.
BEAT
Thank you for your assistance, Doctor, but we have no further need of your input. You will shortly die.
But don’t let that trouble you. So will everything else in recorded history. With two rather handsome exceptions.
Think about what you’re doing.
Thinking about it, perfectly fine with it. So now, old me. Shall I tell you what I did with your TARDIS? So we can scooch off out of here?
Oh, no, no, I have a better idea. Why not take the Doctor’s?
He might find some way out of his ropes, and use his own ship to escape. He doesn’t know where mine is, so if we steal his we eliminate his only opportunity for egress.
Ooh. I like the way you think. So ruthless. So vengeful. So... me. His ship it is, then.
Jemima will stop you.
Really? She might struggle to do that when she’s dead.
You killed her?
I think so. They all blend into one after a while.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 103
You killed his companion? Oh, I’ve always wanted to do that.
I've a feeling she was new, I’m not sure she counts.
There was no need to kill her!

Oh, need, need, need. That’s your answer every time, isn’t it? ‘You didn’t need to do that’. What an inane response. Well, of course I didn’t need to do it, you cretin, I never need to do it. If I needed to do it, it wouldn’t be fun.
I have no need to kill you either, Doctor. But that will not stop me. Goodbye. You will not be missed.
Love to all my victims.
THEY CROSS TO THE TARDIS. PAUSE. NOTHING HAPPENS
Where’s the key?
What key?
His key.
His key, you had it last, didn’t you?
No, you did.
I rather think not. You hid it, remember, I recall you saying exactly that.
No, you hid it when you were possessing my body. You heard my voice, but it was you saying it.
I - actually, you may be right.
Gosh, this is all needlessly complicated, isn’t it?
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 104
In that incarnation, you can talk. - Oh, of course! That’s where I put it!
HE HOOKS IT OUT OF THE DOCTOR’S POCKET
You left it in the Doctor’s pocket?
Don’t overthink things.
Are you quite finished?
Goodbye, Doctor.
Goodbye.
(THEY ENTER THE TARDIS. IT DEMATERIALISES. AFTER A SECOND THE
STARTS STRUGGLING AGAINST THE ROPES)
Well, they were correct about me escaping my bonds. You don’t hang around Houdini without learning...
HE SHRUGS THEM OFF
. the ropes. Ah. How disappointing. A clever bit of wordplay and no-one to hear it. Wasted.
Vessel will impact with hypertunnel in one minute. This is your last chance to evacuate.
One minute? Yes, might need to deal with that. If I don’t want to be exploded.
HE CROSSES TO A CONTROL BANK. TAPS CONTROLS
If I can adjust the navigation settings, I -
HE PAUSES
But... it’s a warzone out there. Millions died fighting to control that hypertunnel.. If I let this ship crash and destroy it... the battle ends. They’re all saved. If I die... they live...
Vessel will impact in thirty seconds.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 105
Right. Well, this is a tight spot.
THE ALARMS BLARE
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 106
51. INT. JARVILL SHIP
(ALL IS FRANTIC ON THE BRIDGE. BARON JARVILL IS SHOUTING DOWN A COMMUNICATOR)
Malgrove! Malgrove, come in! This is Baron Jarvill! What are you
doing, man?!
No response from the enemy ship, Baron. It will strike the hypertunnel in three... two... one...
THERE IS A DEVASTATING EXPLOSION ON THE SCREEN
Sir. Both the ship and the Hypertunnel have been completely obliterated.
CLOSING THEME
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 107

NEW MASTER: I am the Master. And you... know the rest.
SEBASTIAN: The Master.
NEW MASTER: In the flesh.
SEBASTIAN: The notorious renegade Time Lord. Destroyer of worlds. Murderer of billions.
NEW MASTER: Oh, stop, stop, you’re making me blush.
SALRON: The Master? Father Sebastian, we must destroy him. He will betray us!
SEBASTIAN: No. No, Salron, I do not think he will. If he wished our endeavours neutralized, he could easily have eliminated us when he arrived, when we were not aware of his presence. And yet we still live. Why?
SALRON: I do not know.
NEW MASTER: Come on, come on, you can do it.
SEBASTIAN: He requires something of us...
NEW MASTER: Exactly, you’re very astute. I suppose that’s why you’re Cult Leader and not just some common or garden cultist, like Salron here.
SEBASTIAN: Tell us then. What is it that you desire?
NEW MASTER: Why, like I said. To help you, dear chap, just to help you. What else could I want?

DECAYED MASTER: Oh, no, no, I have a better idea. Why not take the Doctor’s?
DECAYED MASTER: He might find some way out of his ropes, and use his own ship to escape. He doesn’t know where mine is, so if we steal his we eliminate his only opportunity for egress.
NEW MASTER: Ooh. I like the way you think. So ruthless. So vengeful. So... me. His ship it is, then.
DOCTOR: Jemima will stop you.
NEW MASTER: Really? She might struggle to do that when she’s dead.
DOCTOR: You killed her?
NEW MASTER: I think so. They all blend into one after a while.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 103
DECAYED MASTER: You killed his companion? Oh, I’ve always wanted to do that.
NEW MASTER: I've a feeling she was new, I’m not sure she counts.
DOCTOR: There was no need to kill her!
NEW MASTER: Oh, need, need, need. That’s your answer every time, isn’t it? ‘You didn’t need to do that’. What an inane response. Well, of course I didn’t need to do it, you cretin, I never need to do it. If I needed to do it, it wouldn’t be fun.
DECAYED MASTER: I have no need to kill you either, Doctor. But that will not stop me. Goodbye. You will not be missed.
NEW MASTER: Love to all my victims.
DECAYED MASTER: Where’s the key?
NEW MASTER: What key?
DECAYED MASTER: His key.
NEW MASTER: His key, you had it last, didn’t you?
DECAYED MASTER: No, you did.
NEW MASTER: I rather think not. You hid it, remember, I recall you saying exactly that.
DECAYED MASTER: No, you hid it when you were possessing my body. You heard my voice, but it was you saying it.
NEW MASTER: I - actually, you may be right.
DOCTOR: Gosh, this is all needlessly complicated, isn’t it?
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 104
NEW MASTER: In that incarnation, you can talk. - Oh, of course! That’s where I put it!
DECAYED MASTER: You left it in the Doctor’s pocket?
NEW MASTER: Don’t overthink things.
DOCTOR: Are you quite finished?
NEW MASTER: Goodbye, Doctor.
DECAYED MASTER: Goodbye.
DECAYED MASTER: (THEY ENTER THE TARDIS. IT DEMATERIALISES. AFTER A SECOND THE
DOCTOR: STARTS STRUGGLING AGAINST THE ROPES)
DOCTOR: Well, they were correct about me escaping my bonds. You don’t hang around Houdini without learning...
DOCTOR: . the ropes. Ah. How disappointing. A clever bit of wordplay and no-one to hear it. Wasted.
ALARM: Vessel will impact with hypertunnel in one minute. This is your last chance to evacuate.
DOCTOR: One minute? Yes, might need to deal with that. If I don’t want to be exploded.
DOCTOR: If I can adjust the navigation settings, I -
DOCTOR: But... it’s a warzone out there. Millions died fighting to control that hypertunnel.. If I let this ship crash and destroy it... the battle ends. They’re all saved. If I die... they live...
ALERT: Vessel will impact in thirty seconds.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 105
DOCTOR: Right. Well, this is a tight spot.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 106
DOCTOR WHO: (ALL IS FRANTIC ON THE BRIDGE. BARON JARVILL IS SHOUTING DOWN A COMMUNICATOR)
BARON: Malgrove! Malgrove, come in! This is Baron Jarvill! What are you
BARON: doing, man?!
GORLAN: No response from the enemy ship, Baron. It will strike the hypertunnel in three... two... one...
GORLAN: Sir. Both the ship and the Hypertunnel have been completely obliterated.
DOCTOR WHO: THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 107

elements.text: PART FOUR
OPENING THEME
52. INT. CLOISTERS TRANSFER ROOM
(FLASHBACK. WITH A BLAZE OF ANDROZANI-LIKE REGENERATION ENERGY,
THE NEW MASTER SNAPS AWAKE - THE DECAYED MASTER’S MIND NOW WITHIN)
GASP OF WAKING
Well?
New hands. New eyes. New... everything. No pain! How... wondrous!
Excellent. It appears the transfer was successful.
Excellent. All praise the Heretic!
I... Where am I?
Our home. There will be some initial disorientation. Do not worry, it will soon pass.
I remember the pain... but before that... (BEAT) I was attacked. Ruined. Destroyed!
Calm! Calm! It is over now.
I... I... Yes. I yet live...
Very much so. See what remains of your former existence.
BEAT
Is that what I was? That creature there? That was me?
It is what you became.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 108
To think I was left in that. Trapped in that horror. If you had not saved me... And he lives in there now? The one who attacked me?
This is his body I inhabit?
It is.
How apt. The punishment fits the crime.
there long. Destroy that travesty.
Oh, we intend to.
Incinerate it as he incinerated me.
(BEAT) Let him not live
With pleasure. Do not trouble yourself. Come. There is no need to
look upon him further. This way.
Where do you take me?
You will see. Brother Salron! - Prepare the other.
I shall, Father.
SEBASTIAN LEADS THE NEW MASTER FROM THE ROOM, INTO:
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 109
53. INT. CLOISTERS CORRIDOR (CONTINUOUS
SEBASTIAN LEADS THE NEW MASTER ALONG
Well? I know you have saved me for some reason, now would be an
opportune moment to reveal it.
So untrusting. Through here.
THEY EXIT INTO A NEW ROOM
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 110
54. INT. CLOISTERS ANTE-ROOM (CONTINUOUS
SEBASTIAN LEADS THE NEW MASTER IN
Here we are.
My TARDIS!
In a manner of speaking, yes. It is certainly yours now...
I do not understand.
It matters not if you do. Please. Take it. You may depart.
PAUSE
No. This is a ruse. A stratagem. No-one would help me without reason.
We are a religious order. We seek the good of all.
And yet you are willing to eliminate my attacker?
There is no good in him. That is why we saved you! It is his obliteration we seek.
I see. And you wish nothing from me? No boon, no promise?
Nothing.
PAUSE
Very well. I shall take you at your word. But be warned. If this is some trick... I promise I will destroy you.
I would expect nothing less.
PAUSE
Goodbye. We shall not meet again.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 111
HE CLIMBS INTO THE TARDIS. AS IT STARTS DEMATERIALISING —-
That much is certainly true.
SEBASTIAN EXITS AS THE DEMATERIALISATION FINISHES
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 112
55. INT. CLOISTERS TRANSFER ROOM
(SALRON IS UNCLAMPING A WAKING DECAYED MASTER - NOW WITH THE NEW MASTER’S MIND WITHIN - FROM THE TRANSFERENCE MACHINE. SEBASTIAN
This one is coming round, Father. He, too. is disorientated. He has no memory of us...

That is to be expected. That brain is broken. His healthier mind will not work well within it. The other has departed. Soon the limitation effect will weave its magic on him too, cloud his mind. He will not remember us. He will spread his disease throughout history. When it unravels, we shall be ready.
And this one?
Must be destroyed. Kill him and the anomaly becomes unbreakable.
The effect will be compounded. With his own weapon, perhaps? The irony would be... amusing. Where is it...?
(HE SEARCHES THE DECAYED MASTER’S CLOTHES. BUT THE DECAYED MASTER WAKES AND GRABS HIM)
Agh! Let go!
Who are you? Why do you cause me pain?
Release him!
Agh! My hand!
What’s that? Is my grip a little too (EFFORT) tight?
AND WITH A CRUNCH, HE BREAKS SEBASTIAN’S HAND
SCREAMS IN AGONY
Father!!!
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 113
Keep back! If you wish to remain alive.
HE DRAWS HIS TCE
Don’t shoot.
Why not? I don’t know who you are, what you want. I care nothing for you. Your lives are meaningless. Only as potential victims can you please me. I would enjoy watching you die.
(PAINED) No. You don’t understand. (LYING) We tried to stop him!
Who?
Your other self. You recall?
This means nothing to me.
You tried to rescue your earlier self. On Terserus. But the pain drove him mad. He seized your body as a chance to escape. Left you in that wrecked form.
I... Yes. This sounds in some way... familiar...
We could not prevent it. We teleported you here, but -
Teleport, yes. I recall that. Through... there...
Let us live, we would assist you!
No! I need no help. I am the Master! There’s a clue in the name. I will fix this myself!
HE RUNS FROM THE ROOM
He’1l be heading for the teleport!
I know! (THEY BOTH RUN OUT AFTER HIM. FADE)
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 114
52. INT. CLOISTERS TELEPORT ROOM [MOMENTS LATER]
(FADE UP. LAST FEW MOMENTS OF A TELEPORT EFFECT AS SEBASTIAN AND
RUN IN)
Too late. We’ve lost him! He’ll go back to his old TARDIS! He’ll escape!
PAUSE
EVIL LAUGH
Father? Is something wrong? You seem... amused... We were to kill him! To make the anomaly unbreakable!
Of course I am. He cannot travel far as he is now. He is weak. The universe is not short of bounty hunters... and the Cult needs its riches no longer.
But if he escapes... If he survives...
If he does, what can he do? We have nothing to fear. Together the Two Masters are soon to destroy eternity. We will never see them again.
AS IN 47, THE SOUNDS SPEED UP AND WE RETURN TO THE PRESENT
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 115
53. INT. TARDIS
(THE TWO MASTERS IN THE DOCTOR’S TARDIS, OPERATING THE CONTROLS AS IT FLIES. THE CLOISTER BELLS TOLLS. ALARMS RING. THE SHIP JUDDERS)
Adjust this... compensate for that...
Shall I drive?
No, you don’t know where we’re going.
It’s hardly a smooth ride.
That’s not my fault. It’s the gaps in time. These readings suggest they’re increasing in number. Spreading. There’s precious little of history left.
Even though we have returned to our original bodies.
Seemingly so. I suppose once the sickness enters and multiplies, it hardly matters if the original germ is neutralised. We infected the universe and now the illness spreads.
And you believe this all to be the work of the... ‘Cult of the Heretic’?
Oh, undoubtedly. It fits their objectives to aT.
You said you would explain who they were.

Yes, yes, of course I did. Sorry, forgot. The Heretic was one of our kind, you see. Back in the day. He was executed. Or sent to Shada. I’m not entirely sure which, the records on the subject aren’t exactly comprehensive. But the important thing is that he didn’t wholly subscribe to the traditional orthodoxy of our people.
That much would seem apparent from the name.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 116

Yes. Good point. Although it didn’t seem that way initially. He didn’t head out into the universe to start mucking about with it like you, me, the Doctor, and everyone. No, he sat at home, like a good little Gallifreyan and observed. And it was what he observed that was the problem.
Yes?
He saw a universe that was sick. Spoilt and ruined by its own inhabitants, mortally wounded. There was no good in it, only evil.
They say that of me too.
He saw violence, anger, war and death, everywhere he looked. An eternity gone wrong. It revolted him. And he resolved to put it right.
How?
The only way a Time Lord would think to cure the mortally wounded. Regeneration.
He wanted to regenerate the universe?
In a nutshell, yes. Destroy it all and replace it with something better of his own devising.
Even I have not had the audacity to attempt the destruction of everything.

Well, you’ve got to have ambitions, haven’t you? But actually, it wasn’t quite everything. As he and his followers considered themselves the only healthy beings in the cosmos, he decreed their right to survive.
Through using this Anomaly Cage.
Exactly. You’re very smart, I could grow to like you.
Get on with it.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 117

Although you can go off people. (BEAT) The Cage protects you from the manipulation of time. It rewrites it around you, shapes it to fit. Destroy your own history and you remain unaffected. Paradoxes drift past like a summer breeze.
So it is what you would use to survive disrupting your own past by, to pick an example at random, murdering an earlier iteration of yourself?
You’re not still angry about that, are you? Oh come on, you’re alive. That makes it attempted murder at worst, get it right.
Attempted murder? Merely attempted? You expect me to revel in your incompetence? I would not have attempted, I would have succeeded.
Whatever happened to forgive and forget?
You tried to kill me. Condemned me to exist as a living curse. If you were anyone else I would not be standing here talking to you, you would be dead.

And that’s precisely the point. I’m you and you’re me and we’re both still here. That’s why I picked Terserus. Because I knew you survived it, it’s what happened to me! In my past. The Cult would think I was doing their bidding, but in reality I was just leaving things the way they always were.
Really? Do you expect applause for this piece of cunning? Appreciation?
I expect gratitude. If someone was going to leave you like that, wouldn’t you rather it was me that was responsible, instead of the Doctor? Or some random chap off the street?
I would rather pain did not course through my every nerve at even the slightest movement.
You’re not going to let this one go, are you? Shall we just say the Cult fogged my mind or something and forget about it?
No.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 118

Excellent. Where were we? Ah, yes. The Cage. The Heretic had only got as far as the design stage when the Time Lords caught up with him. He’d swanned off into the great wide yonder to found his religion, you see. Gathering followers from myriad races. Had it been built, all he’d require was a catalyst to initiate the collapse of the universe, then some of his own Time Lord biodata to trigger its regeneration. The latter proved tricky when he was killed, obviously.
So we provided a replacement?

I can’t imagine they wouldn’t have stolen the biodata from one of us when we were in their power. And our temporal displacement provided the infection they required as the catalyst. We were the computer virus that disrupts the system before they reboot it.
We gave them everything.
And they left us to die. Yes, it’s the ingratitude that hurts the most. Fortunately, revenge isn’t far behind them.
THE TARDIS JUDDERS
I hope not. I do not believe the Doctor’s ship is built for much more of this. We cannot traverse the no-time endlessly. We will eventually be destroyed.
Oh, I don’t doubt it, but I’m not merely hoping our vengeance is close. I’m speaking from a point of certainty. You see -
HE TAPS MORE CONTROLS THEN STEPS AWAY WITH A FLOURISH
I’ve found the Cage.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 119
54. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (MAIN ROOM
(SEBASTIAN ADDRESSING THE CULTISTS. A REASONABLY SIZED ROOM IN A
TYPE ENVIRONMENT, SOME LIGHT TECHNOLOGY ACTIVE. MONITORS HUM, READOUTS BEEP)
This is a wondrous day. The day we have prepared for for many years. The day of regeneration. All praise the Heretic!
All praise the Heretic!
Our catalyst has triggered the obliteration of time. It is only we who will survive. It shall be our great task to remake the universe. Build it anew. And build it better.
All praise the Heretic!
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 120
55. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (ENVIRONMENT
(COMPUTERS TICKING OVER. THE TARDIS MATERIALISES. THE MASTERS EXIT, CLOSING DOOR BEHIND)

This place was remarkably easy to locate, of course. They’ve built a craft to withstand the obliteration of the universe. So, when history itself is vanishing, you simply scan the dead sections of time and voila. The Cage will be hidden in the real universe, but in the gaps it’ll be the only thing you can find. Clever, eh?
Yes, you’re very ingenious.
You can’t wait to be me, can you?
Their domain is... bigger than I expected.
They only call it a Cage. It doesn’t have bars. It’s sort of a Space-time craft. Only it flies through paradoxes rather than the vortex.
I see. So our intentions now are to kill the entire Cult as painfully as possible and take this ship over? Then reboot the universe in our own image?
You know, that’s exactly what I was thinking. Those very words. We’re incredibly simpatico.

So if that is our intent, we should proceed with alacrity, yes? These appear to be environment controls... if you’re correct that the Cult consists of multiple species, the atmosphere here must be carefully balanced and controlled. If we interfere with the air
supply...
Ooh. Yes. Now that’s my kind of plan!
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 121
56. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (MAIN ROOM
Through carefully managed application of the catalyst’s biological data we can shape our new creation in any way we desire. The choices are, literally, infinite.
A PANEL BEEPS
Father. Sensors register a forcefield breach.
GENERAL CONSTERNATION
Calm, calm. This is easily solved.
But if the shields fail, there’ll be nothing to protect us from the temporal erosion.
Such a breach is impossible. There is nothing outside to invade us. This is a glitch in the system, nothing more.
CALMED
Where is this so called breach?
The second storeroom.
Then kindly investigate the issue, Salron. And repair it.
I obey.
HE EXITS
There must be no mistakes.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL)
57. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (STOREROOM
(THE MASTERS ARE OPERATING COMPUTER CONTROLS. CULTIST IS
OUTSIDE)
Now, if we attach the extraction lines to the -
Wait.
THEY HALT
Someone approaches.
Excellent. I think we know what to do
I look forward to it.
CULTIST ENTERS
Hello there!
You?
about them, don’t we?
Page 122
Yes, us! Good to see you again. Brother Salron, isn’t it? Are you Still one of that ‘Cult of the Heretic’ mob? Wanting to regenerate the entire universe? Such an insane scheme. Maybe you need to see
(THE DECAYED MASTER SHOOTS CULTIST 2,
Aaaagh!
HIM DOWN)
Why did you do that? I was in the middle of a bit!
You were wasting time. There is no need for prattle.
THE DECAYED MASTER RETURNS TO HIS WORK
I wasn’t prattling, I was building to something.
He needed to die. He might have alerted the others.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 123
‘Maybe you need to see a shrink’! That’s what I was going to say.
SILENCE
Because it would have been quite amusing. You know. With ‘shrink’ being slang for a psychiatrist? And because I was going to ‘shrink’ him? It would have been, sort of... a pun. You understand?
PAUSE
Are you finished?
With this audience, certainly.
Then get on with it. I desire their deaths to be as painful as possible.
(BITTERLY) Yes, sir.
THEY CONTINUE THEIR WORK
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 124
58. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (MAIN ROOM
SEBASTIAN OPERATES CONTROLS. A READOUT BEEPS
There, my brethren. It is done. All history... has been erased. Praise be the Heretic!
Praise be the Heretic!

It is time for his dream to become a reality. It is now but the simple matter of generating a replacement. Converting the Time Lord’s regeneration energies and starting everything anew. Making it all... better.
BEGINNING TO COUGH AND SPLUTTER
We must choose the new existence carefully. We will be its creators, we will be as gods. We should tread carefully with that responsibility. Be benevolent rulers in his name. All hail the Heretic!
(CHOKING) All... hail... Gah! Air!
My... brethren... what... ails you? (COUGHS) What...
CHOKING AND EXPIRING EVERYWHERE
(STRUGGLING TO SPEAK) What treachery is this? Who has... betrayed usS...?
SEBASTIAN DROPS TO THE FLOOR AS THE MASTERS ENTER THE ROOM
As if you need to ask.
(WEAK) No...
All dead. All bar hin...
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 125

Yes. I went for a slightly unusual mix to air. Fatal to everyone except him. Humans aren’t killed, they’re just left incapacitated. didn’t want it to be quick. I want him to see his murderers. Understand his error of judgement.
Ah, I see. That is the price he must pay for his treachery. He must... suffer. I am glad. (TO SEBASTIAN) Hello. I believe I made you a promise...
You... two...
Yes! Me! Us! Fancy seeing you here, Sebastian! Isn’t ita -
THE DECAYED MASTER SHOOTS SEBASTIAN, SHRINKING HIM
Aaargh!
Oh come on! Can you allow me to say at least one?
Let me guess. ‘Fancy seeing you here. Isn’t it a small world’.
BEAT
No, that wasn’t it.
What was it then?
SILENCE
Honestly, why do you persist with this witless juvenilia? Or do you truly believe the death agonies they feel when their bodies are crushed down to Lilliputian size are as nothing unless they
are also forced to listen to an inane play on words?
I find it amusing.
I do not kill to amuse myself. I kill for power.
Kill joy more like. You know, you used to be fun. Back when it was
all pointy beards and nehru jackets. Whatever happened to that?
I
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 126
You happened.
Am I really going to be stuck ruling a new universe with you? Out of all my other incarnations, this is the version I end up with? Couldn’t I have had Mister Velveteen, or the snake?
You picked me. This regeneration. You picked me. This was not my choice.

Well, just try to enjoy yourself, can’t you? Find some pleasure in your work. This is all we’ve ever wanted, isn’t it? Through this mental interface we design our new universe. Throw this lever and the regeneration energies force it into being. All history. At our fingertips. If you can’t smile at that when can you?
It is... that simple?
The Heretic knew his stuff. Think about it. Every single life.
Ours to control. We are the Masters... and they will obey us!
I suppose it is... good.
It’s not good, it’s magnificent! Every one else, ever... dead! An entire new universe ready to be born under our rule! An eternity to command. And best of all - no Doctor!
SOMEWHERE OFF, A TARDIS IS MATERIALISING
What - is - that?
Oh, you have got to be kidding me.
THEY RUN FROM THE ROOM. FADE
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 127
59. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (STOREROOM) (CONTINUOUS
THE SECOND TARDIS IS MATERIALISING AS THE MASTERS RUN IN
No! Another TARDIS!
Yes. I think it might be mine.
THE DOCTOR EMERGES FROM IT
Hello boys. Did you miss me?
Doctor!
How did you find us?
How did you get here?
Oh, it was simplicity itself. You were heading for something that could survive the erasure of history. So once history had been erased, your location would be pretty easy to ascertain.
Of course.
Much the same technique as we used.
But the spaceship! It was crashing into the Hypertunnel! You could never have found my TARDIS quickly enough.
Oh, I didn’t need to. I was in the missile bay, remember? I merely hopped inside one missile and shot myself into space, out of range of the explosion.
Ah. I see.
When the Gorlan ship was destroyed, your TARDIS was one of the few items to remain unscathed. As the missiles were energy seeking, and TARDISes use a lot of energy -
You would have flown straight to it.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 128
Correct.
And since you’d very helpfully left me a portable force-field generator -
You did what?
No! Yes. Well, maybe I did, but there was no harm in it! I couldn’t see the thing being of any use to him, it was almost out of power.

Fortunately it still retained enough to enable me to reach your ship. Which was damaged from having you fly it so breaking in was an easy job. I simply had to use my own key, the lock wasn’t in great shape.
Very clever.
Ingenious.
Thank you.
But it is the last moment of ingenuity you will ever display. Anything you wish to say before the execution?
Well, I -
Not you. Me.
Really?
In this particular case I am willing to make an exception.
Why thank you. Most kind. Doctor. You are, quite literally, no fun any more. Your life expectancy is extremely short.
MASTER/DECAYED MASTER: Goodbye, Doctor!!!
(THEY BOTH SHOOT HIM WITH THEIR TCES. BUT THE BLASTS BOUNCE OF AN
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 129
FIELD)
What on —- ?
Why is he not - ?

Oh, did I not say? Your adaptation of the TARDIS forcefields clued me in on how to make my own portable version. The original might have run out of juice... but the one from this TARDIS, your other TARDIS, has no such trouble.
You’re the gift that keeps on giving, aren’t you?
I could hardly have expected that.
Trouble in paradise? Stands to reason I suppose... What’s through here...
HE BRUSHES PAST THEM
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 130
60. INT. THE ANOMALY CAGE (MAIN ROOM) (CONTINUOUS
THE MASTERS FOLLOW THE DOCTOR IN
The assembled Cult of the Heretic, I presume. All dead. Will no amount of bodies ever satisfy your hunger for destruction?
Oh, I think our current tally of ‘everyone in history who ever lived’ is probably sufficient.
Not quite everyone. The Doctor remains a glaring admission in our list of victims. But that forcefield cannot last long. Soon it will decay.
So all we need do is wait. Then we can complete the set.
I’m sure you’re very patient. And with history dead, you’ve a lot of time to fill...
Oh, my dear Doctor, history isn’t dead. It’s merely resting...
Before being restored in whatever way you desire. Is this the equipment designed to program the regeneration?
Step away from those controls.
Oh, I wouldn’t worry. That’s the problem with this forcefield. I can’t actually touch anything.
So you can’t interfere?
No.
Ha! Oh, this is delightful! And the moment the forcefield drops, we kill you.
You survived the explosion merely to join us here and experience a more personal form of death.
Glorious!
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 131
Well. The rest of time was destroyed. Where else was I going to go? (HE WALKS AROUND) I’ll say one thing for the Cult, they knew their stuff.
You were already aware of them, weren’t you?
I helped stopped the Heretic himself. Many years ago. Or last week. One or the other. I’m not really sure. I thought the rest of the Cult had been neutralised.
Well, they have been now, yes.
Am I to understand that the pair of you plan to restore history in your own image?
Correct.
We haven’t quite finessed the precise details yet, but yes, that’s the basic idea.
And which one of you will be in charge?
MASTER/NEW MASTER: Me. (THEN MORE INSISTENT, TO EACH OTHER) Me!
Yes, I thought this might happen. That’s the trouble with meeting your others selves. You don’t always get on. Trust someone who knows.
Mere teething troubles. We shall rule in harmony.
We shall rule together!
Really? Are you certain of that? There can be only one Master, surely? By definition. There’s a clue in the name.
I see what you’re doing, Doctor.
You are trying to sow discord between us. You will fail.
THE TWO MASTERS by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 132

I’m just stating the facts. If the pair of you reboot the universe and take charge together, well... you’1l just confuse your new subjects. No man can be the servant of two masters, no matter what Goldoni might think.
They will learn.

And can you really submit to the will of the other? You have very different personalities. I’m sure you’ll disagree on matters of importance. Who gets final say? With only two of you there is no casting vote.
You think I would argue with my own self?
I suspect you already have.
PAUSE
You know, he’s sort of got a point.
He might be correct, to a degree.
